headline.main: TOO MANY LONDON HOTELS.; So Says Earl of Bessborough -- Motors Cause of Short Stays of Guests.

byline.original: Special Cable to THE NEW YORK TIMES

docs.abstract: Earl of Bessborough declares there are too many hotels in London, annual meeting, Gordon Hotels Co
docs.lead_paragraph: LONDON, July 23. -- The Earl of Bessborough, presiding to-day at the annual meeting of the Gordon Hotels Company, took a very pessimistic view of the London hotel situation. Except perhaps for a few weeks in the very height of the season, said he, London had too many hotels, and competition had become very severe.

headline.main: THE HOTEL MAN'S RIGHT TO INTRUDE; He May Enter Any Guest's Room, Says Court, Ruling Under 300-Year-Old Law. ONE JUSTICE DISSENTS McLaughlin Calls Reasoning of His Appellate Associates Absurd -- Decision In Grand Union Case.

docs.abstract: NYS Sup Ct Appellate Div Judge Ingraham decision upholds hotel proprietor's right to enter guests' rooms; cites 300-yr-old Brit ct decision in denying Mrs C DeWolf's $10,000 suit against NYC Grand Union Hotel
docs.lead_paragraph: In a decision sustaining the court below, the Appellate Division decided yesterday that a hotel proprietor could not be held in damages for invasion of the privacy of a guest's room. The opinion was written by Justice Ingraham, and Justices Lambert, Patterson, and Clarke concurred.

headline.main: THEY FITTED THE TRAMP.; Imprisoned Shoe Dealer Could See That Through the Door.

byline.original: Special to The New York Times

docs.lead_paragraph: NEWARK, Jan. 11. -- Louis Hahn, who is the owner of a little shoe store at 415 Mulberry Street, found business dull to-day, so he decided to make some sort of sidewalk display, although he had been notified not to put out a showcase.

headline.main: THIRD AVENUE ROAD DEBT; Negotiations for Taking It Up Dropped by Kuhn, Loeb & Co. NEWS SURPRISES WALL STREET Question of President Elias's Retention Had Nothing to Do with Failure to Agree, Mr. Lauterbach Says.

keywords.name: glocations
keywords.value: NEW YORK. MISCELLANY: CHURCHES, EXCHANGES, HOTELS, REAL ESTATE, SOCIETIES

docs.abstract: Waldorf-Astoria Hotel Incorporated to Protect Its Name
docs.lead_paragraph: Wall Street had a surprise yesterday in the announcement, made by Kuhn, Loeb Co., that they had dropped negotiations for taking up the debt of the Third Avenue Railroad Company. The news was particularly sudden, because it had been preceded by days in which continual official announcements were made of satisfactory progress in the negotiations, and rumors of hitches which had cropped up now and then were almost invariably denied with promptness.

headline.main: PEOPLE AT THE HOTELS; Many Men and Women of National Prominence Come to Town. A FEAST FOR THE CURIOUS An ex-President, Senators Congressmen, Judges, Millionaires, and Others Make Up the Show -- What Goes On in the Corridors.

keywords.name: glocations
keywords.value: NEW YORK. MISCELLANY, CHURCHES, EXCHANGES, HOTELS, REAL ESTATE, SOCIETIES

docs.lead_paragraph: The coming and going in this city of men and women of National prominence never ceases. As a temporary stopping place for "celebrities" New York, with the exception of Washington, is pre-eminent, so much so, in fact, that the genuine Manhattanite regards such peregrinations as a matter of course, but to the out-of-town man the point of view is different.
